natural problem: Three friends have a total of 6 identical pencils, and each one has at least one pencil. In how many ways can this happen?
natural solution: The largest number of pencils that any friend can have is four. There are 3 ways that this can happen: $(4,1,1)$, $(1,4,1)$ and $(1,1,4)$. There are 6 ways one person can have 3 pencils: $(3,2,1)$, $(3,1,2)$, $(2,3,1)$, $(2,1,3)$, $(1,2,3)$ and $(1,3,2)$.
There is only one way all three can have two pencils each: $(2,2,2)$. The total number of possibilities is $3+6+1=\boxed{10}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: nat
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = 6"
and h1 : "A > 0"
and h2 : "B > 0"
and h3 : "C > 0"
shows  "card {(A, B, C). A + B + C = 6 \<and> A > 0 \<and> B > 0 \<and> C > 0} = 10"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three friends have a total of 6 identical pencils, and each one has at least one pencil. In how many ways can this happen? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 The largest number of pencils that any friend can have is four. There are 3 ways that this can happen: $(4,1,1)$, $(1,4,1)$ and $(1,1,4)$. There are 6 ways one person can have 3 pencils: $(3,2,1)$, $(3,1,2)$, $(2,3,1)$, $(2,1,3)$, $(1,2,3)$ and $(1,3,2)$.
 There is only one way all three can have two pencils each: $(2,2,2)$. The total number of possibilities is $3+6+1=\boxed{10}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: nat
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = 6"
and h1 : "A > 0"
and h2 : "B > 0"
and h3 : "C > 0"
shows  "card {(A, B, C). A + B + C = 6 \<and> A > 0 \<and> B > 0 \<and> C > 0} = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many ordered triples of positive integers $(A, B, C)$ satisfy the equation $A + B + C = 6$? The final answer is 10.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and friends :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 3"
and h1 : "sum friends {1..n} = 6"
and h2 : "\<forall>i \<in> {1..n}. friends i \<ge> 1"
shows  "\<exists>!p. p = 10"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three friends have a total of 6 identical pencils, and each one has at least one pencil. In how many ways can this happen? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 The largest number of pencils that any friend can have is four. There are 3 ways that this can happen: $(4,1,1)$, $(1,4,1)$ and $(1,1,4)$. There are 6 ways one person can have 3 pencils: $(3,2,1)$, $(3,1,2)$, $(2,3,1)$, $(2,1,3)$, $(1,2,3)$ and $(1,3,2)$.
 There is only one way all three can have two pencils each: $(2,2,2)$. The total number of possibilities is $3+6+1=\boxed{10}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and friends :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 3"
and h1 : "sum friends {1..n} = 6"
and h2 : "\<forall>i \<in> {1..n}. friends i \<ge> 1"
shows  "\<exists>!p. p = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There are 3 friends, and the total number of items they have is 6. Each friend has at least 1 item. What is the unique value of $p$ such that $p = 10$?

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "(int, int, int) \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b c. f (a, b, c) \<longleftrightarrow> a + b + c = 6 \<and> a > 0 \<and> b > 0 \<and> c > 0"
shows  "card {abc. f abc} = 10"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three friends have a total of 6 identical pencils, and each one has at least one pencil. In how many ways can this happen? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 The largest number of pencils that any friend can have is four. There are 3 ways that this can happen: $(4,1,1)$, $(1,4,1)$ and $(1,1,4)$. There are 6 ways one person can have 3 pencils: $(3,2,1)$, $(3,1,2)$, $(2,3,1)$, $(2,1,3)$, $(1,2,3)$ and $(1,3,2)$.
 There is only one way all three can have two pencils each: $(2,2,2)$. The total number of possibilities is $3+6+1=\boxed{10}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "(int, int, int) \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b c. f (a, b, c) \<longleftrightarrow> a + b + c = 6 \<and> a > 0 \<and> b > 0 \<and> c > 0"
shows  "card {abc. f abc} = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: How many positive integer solutions are there for the equation $a + b + c = 6$? The final answer is 10.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes ways :: nat and pencils :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sum_list (map pencils [1, 2, 3]) = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. i \<in> {1, 2, 3} \<longrightarrow> pencils i \<ge> 1"
shows  "ways = 10"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three friends have a total of 6 identical pencils, and each one has at least one pencil. In how many ways can this happen? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 The largest number of pencils that any friend can have is four. There are 3 ways that this can happen: $(4,1,1)$, $(1,4,1)$ and $(1,1,4)$. There are 6 ways one person can have 3 pencils: $(3,2,1)$, $(3,1,2)$, $(2,3,1)$, $(2,1,3)$, $(1,2,3)$ and $(1,3,2)$.
 There is only one way all three can have two pencils each: $(2,2,2)$. The total number of possibilities is $3+6+1=\boxed{10}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes ways :: nat and pencils :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sum_list (map pencils [1, 2, 3]) = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. i \<in> {1, 2, 3} \<longrightarrow> pencils i \<ge> 1"
shows  "ways = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: There are 3 people, each of whom has at least 1 pencil. If the total number of pencils they have is 6, in how many ways can the pencils be distributed among them? The final answer is 10.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: nat
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = 6"
and h1 : "A \<ge> 1"
and h2 : "B \<ge> 1"
and h3 : "C \<ge> 1"
shows  "card { (A, B, C) | A B C. A + B + C = 6 \<and> A \<ge> 1 \<and> B \<ge> 1 \<and> C \<ge> 1 } = 10"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three friends have a total of 6 identical pencils, and each one has at least one pencil. In how many ways can this happen? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 The largest number of pencils that any friend can have is four. There are 3 ways that this can happen: $(4,1,1)$, $(1,4,1)$ and $(1,1,4)$. There are 6 ways one person can have 3 pencils: $(3,2,1)$, $(3,1,2)$, $(2,3,1)$, $(2,1,3)$, $(1,2,3)$ and $(1,3,2)$.
 There is only one way all three can have two pencils each: $(2,2,2)$. The total number of possibilities is $3+6+1=\boxed{10}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: nat
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = 6"
and h1 : "A \<ge> 1"
and h2 : "B \<ge> 1"
and h3 : "C \<ge> 1"
shows  "card { (A, B, C) | A B C. A + B + C = 6 \<and> A \<ge> 1 \<and> B \<ge> 1 \<and> C \<ge> 1 } = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: How many ordered triplets $(A, B, C)$ of positive integers are there such that $A + B + C = 6$? The final answer is 10.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "b \<ge> 1"
and h2 : "c \<ge> 1"
and h3 : "a + b + c = 6"
shows  "number_of_ways a b c = 10"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three friends have a total of 6 identical pencils, and each one has at least one pencil. In how many ways can this happen? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 The largest number of pencils that any friend can have is four. There are 3 ways that this can happen: $(4,1,1)$, $(1,4,1)$ and $(1,1,4)$. There are 6 ways one person can have 3 pencils: $(3,2,1)$, $(3,1,2)$, $(2,3,1)$, $(2,1,3)$, $(1,2,3)$ and $(1,3,2)$.
 There is only one way all three can have two pencils each: $(2,2,2)$. The total number of possibilities is $3+6+1=\boxed{10}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "b \<ge> 1"
and h2 : "c \<ge> 1"
and h3 : "a + b + c = 6"
shows  "number_of_ways a b c = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the number of ways to distribute 6 identical items into three distinct boxes, where each box can contain at least 1 item. The final answer is 10.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "ways = count_partitions 6 3 1"
shows  "ways = 10"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three friends have a total of 6 identical pencils, and each one has at least one pencil. In how many ways can this happen? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 The largest number of pencils that any friend can have is four. There are 3 ways that this can happen: $(4,1,1)$, $(1,4,1)$ and $(1,1,4)$. There are 6 ways one person can have 3 pencils: $(3,2,1)$, $(3,1,2)$, $(2,3,1)$, $(2,1,3)$, $(1,2,3)$ and $(1,3,2)$.
 There is only one way all three can have two pencils each: $(2,2,2)$. The total number of possibilities is $3+6+1=\boxed{10}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "ways = count_partitions 6 3 1"
shows  "ways = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the number of ways to partition 6 into 3 positive integers. The final answer is 10.

and h2 : "b \<ge> 1"

shows  "card {(a, b, c). a + b + c = 6 \<and> a \<ge> 1 \<and> b \<ge> 1 \<and> c \<ge> 1} = 10"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three friends have a total of 6 identical pencils, and each one has at least one pencil. In how many ways can this happen? The final Answer is 10

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "(nat \<Rightarrow> nat) \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>g. f g = (g 1 + g 2 + g 3 = 6 \<and> g 1 \<ge> 1 \<and> g 2 \<ge> 1 \<and> g 3 \<ge> 1)"
shows  "card {g. f g} = 10"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
